item.title: Haiku Generator
item.description: This project produces a random haiku generator. By using texts coming from actual books, a Python script automatically extracts words and outputs a haiku (a text that follows the 5-7-5 syllable rule). Texts were taken from Project Gutenberg, an online library of more than 60,000 books. Among the Python libraries used for this project were SpaCy and SyllaPy. You can learn more about this project by reading this blog post or by checking out the code on Github.

item.title: Bilinguals in the Midwest (BILinMID) Corpus
item.description: This corpus documents the Spanish and English spoken by bilinguals living in the Midwest of the United States. The corpus comprises written transcriptions of the Little Red Riding Hood fairy tale as narrated by several bilingual speakers. These stories were elicited using a children’s book (containing only images, not text) üìñ. Bilingual speakers were either born in the United States or in a Spanish-speaking country (e.g., Mexico, Spain…), and they were fluent in both English and Spanish, though their level of proficiency differed based on individual variables, such as length of residence in the United States, country of birth, etc.

item.title: Phonetic transcription systems you should know
item.description: What is phonetic transcription? Phonetic transcription is the use of phonetic symbols to represent speech. We could say it’s a way to visually represent speech sounds, which is important because orthography often doesn’t represent pronunciation accurately. Each phonetic symbol represents a sound in a spoken utterance. However, which phonetic symbol we use depends on the phonetic transcription system we follow. This means that the same dataset can be transcribed in more than one way.

item.title: Creating a Haiku generator with Python
item.description: What is a haiku? I’m sure you have heard the term haiku at least once in your life. Haiku is a type of short form poetry that originated in Japan üáØüáµ.
